title: The Crown season 3: Olivia Colman's Queen makes debut as country in turmoil
text:
The Crown season 3 promises turmoil for the queen as the full trailer finally dropped just three weeks before release – and Olivia Colman’s debut anything but a happy one.

Queen Elizabeth is seem questioning her time on the throne through a series of flashing images that set up an increasingly divided nation.

As a melodic version of Bob Dylan’s These Times Are A-Changin’ plays in the background, the monarch is deep in thought as preparations for her Silver Jubilee in 1977– marking 25 years on the throne – gets underway.

But she seems anything but happy as the country amid bankruptcy and the Three-Day Week initiative of 1974 (where electricity was rationed to three days a week).

The third series will cover 1964 until 1977 – including Harold Wilson’s time as Prime Minister, the moon landing, the decolonisation of Africa and the Caribbean and Princess Margaret’s affair with Roddy Llewellyn.

‘This country was still great when I came to the throne,’ the Queen is heard saying. ‘All that’s happened on my watch is that the place has fallen apart.’

Margaret starts dicing with danger with a raunchy affair (Picture: Netflix)

Olivia Colman’s Queen Elizabeth looks far from happy (Picture: Netflix)

It seems that she’s not the only one frustrated, as her ‘support acts’ begin to get frustrated at always coming second to Elizabeth and what she has to do.

Princess Margaret (Helena Bonham Carter) is whispering in her ear, seemingly tempted by control as she talks to her lover, declaring herself to be number one of the two sisters.

Then there’s Prince Charles (Josh O’Connor), who’s finding himself torn between falling in love with Camilla Parker-Bowles (Emerald Fennell) and his commitments as a member of the monarchy.

Venting his anger, he looks on the verge of giving up, and is made all the more worse when he’s told by a confidante ‘watch out for your family.’

Charles is torn between his heart and his family duty (Picture: Netflix)

‘They mean well,’ Charles responded, to which he’s told: ‘No, they don’t.’

The trailer ends with Charles and his mother in a furious clash, where it’s revealed that maybe Elizabeth is aware more than most the cost that comes with being in the monarchy.

‘We have all made sacrifices and suppressed who we are,’ she’s heard saying. ‘It is not a choice. It is a duty.’

The trailer’s release comes just 24 hours since it was pulled from the Japan Netflix’s YouTube account after it was uploaded early accidentally.

It didn’t take fans long to spot the error, with the trailer being available for the best part of a day before it was eventually taken down.
